message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient presents with pain in the upper lateral part of the right thigh and tenderness to palpation, which suggests the greater trochanter. The other options, such as acetabulum, femoral head, or lateral femoral cutaneous nerve do not typically cause this type of pain.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's pain is localized to the greater trochanter, and the tenderness during resisted abduction suggests gluteus medius and minimus tendinopathy. The other options would present with different symptoms and signs.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and tenderness suggest a greater trochanteric pain syndrome, which is commonly caused by inflammation of the tendons surrounding the greater trochanter. The other options are less likely given the patient’s symptoms and physical findings.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The location of the pain and tenderness suggest the greater trochanter as the source of pain. The fact that the pain is aggravated by lying on the right side and resisting passive abduction of the leg also supports this diagnosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The location of the tenderness and aggravation of pain while lying on the right side suggest the Greater trochanter as the source of the pain. The other options would have different signs and symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and examination findings suggest greater trochanteric pain syndrome. This condition causes tenderness over the greater trochanter, pain with resisted abduction of the leg, and pain that radiates to the thigh. The other options do not match with the symptoms and examination findings.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest that the most likely source of pain is the greater trochanter. Tenderness to palpation, pain when lying on the affected side, and pain with resisted abduction are all associated with greater trochanteric pain syndrome. X-ray of the pelvis showing no abnormalities eliminates the possibility of acetabular or femoral head pathology. Lateral femoral cutaneous nerve involvement would present with sensory symptoms rather than the pain described by the patient.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The tenderness to palpation over the upper lateral part of the right thigh and pain radiating to the thigh suggest that the greater trochanter is the most likely source of the patient’s pain. A strain of the gluteal medius muscle or bursitis can cause this type of pain, and both are associated with greater trochanteric pain syndrome.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest greater trochanteric pain syndrome. Tenderness to palpation over the upper lateral part of the right thigh and pain aggravated by climbing stairs and lying on his right side are typical symptoms. The other options are less likely as they do not match the patient's symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms described suggest that the most likely source of pain is the greater trochanter, which is the insertion site for several muscles including the gluteus medius and minimus. The tenderness with passive abduction of the right leg also supports this diagnosis. The other options are less likely based on the history and physical examination findings.
